page.title: 03CHEMICALS,TEESSIDE AIRPORT
page.content:
The{British Chrome and Chemical works was founded on the Urlay Nook site 150 years ago originally to make artificial fertilizers, using sulphuric acid. The nearby railway line which opened in 1825 was used to transport the products to the local port of Yarm.
It is a large collection of grey buildings which look very out of place in such a rural area. Steam appears to be one by-product of the manufacture of Chrome, although the plant also has its own{pollution monitors}to check for other gases which may be brought down dissolved in the rain. The buildings and the steam are very{colourful}and impressive at night when they are lit up by many small red and yellow lights. (CONTINUED page 4)
